summary: This FBI administrative communication from the New York Operations Command documents receipt of an international mail letter from the UK addressed to the NYO FBI. The letter includes a copy of a US District Court ruling dismissing allegations against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for lack of jurisdiction, and requests FBI assistance in appealing the action. The sender also submitted a statement about a sexual encounter with Maxwell and photos of items received in exchange for silence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named in a US District Court Southern District of New York civil judgment; allegations of rape in the UK were dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named alongside Ghislaine Maxwell in a US District Court Southern District of New York civil judgment.

connections.description: Both named as defendants in the same civil judgment case (1:20-cv-06928-LLS).

events.title: Court ruling dismissing allegations
events.description: US District Court Southern District of New York ruling in Case 1:20-cv-06928-LLS dismissed allegations of being raped by Ghislaine Maxwell in the UK for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

events.title: FBI receives international mail letter
events.description: NYOC receives an international mail letter from the UK addressed to the NYO FBI, containing the court ruling and a request for FBI assistance in appealing the action.

keyFacts: A US District Court ruling dated November 19, 2020, dismissed allegations of rape against Ghislaine Maxwell in the UK for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.
An individual from the UK sent the ruling to the FBI, requesting assistance in appealing the dismissal and submitted a statement of a sexual encounter with Maxwell.
The sender also provided photos of items they received in exchange for their silence regarding the alleged encounter.
The FBI's Legat London and IA (likely International Affairs or Internal Affairs) were added to the communication for awareness.
The document indicates ongoing international interest and attempts to seek legal recourse related to allegations against Maxwell and Epstein.
